Massachusetts General Laws ch. 186, \u00.proposition: Massachusetts General Laws ch. 186, § 14 establishes that a landlord may not interfere with a tenant's quiet enjoyment of their rental property and provides for damages and attorney’s fees for violations.

*Dartmouth v. Greater N.Y. Corp.*, 352 M.proposition: The covenant of quiet enjoyment has been interpreted as ensuring that tenants have a right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of their rented premises.
*Dartmouth v. Greater N.Y. Corp.*, 352 M.support_reasoning: This opinion concerns a tort action for negligence involving the erection of a traffic sign by a public employee and addresses issues of duty, ministerial acts, and control within the Department of Public Works. It does not involve landlord–tenant law, leases, or the covenant of quiet enjoyment. Therefore, it provides no authority for the proposition that the covenant of quiet enjoyment ensures tenants have a right to undisturbed use and enjoyment of rented premises.
*Dartmouth v. Greater N.Y. Corp.*, 352 M.relevant_excerpt: There was no error in the direction of verdicts for the defendant. The Department of Public Works was in sole charge of the erection of the sign. G. L. c. 85, § 2 (as amended through St. 1951, c. 646, § 1). The defendant as a subordinate employee had no alternative in the action he was ordered to take. He had received the sign ready-made from the department with a detailed sketch allowing him no choice to make changes in the location or in the legend on the sign. It could not properly be found that the defendant was negligent in the performance of this ministerial act.

See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95.proposition: Defendant violated Plaintiff's right to quiet enjoyment by failing to repair the defective electrical wiring in a timely manner, depriving Plaintiff of the full use of the premises. See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95-97 (1982).
See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95.support_reasoning: The case does address interference with quiet enjoyment under G.L. c. 186, § 14, but the interference here is repeated flooding and sewage and other unsanitary conditions, not defective electrical wiring. More importantly, the SJC ultimately vacated the tenant’s $10,000 damages award for interference with quiet enjoyment as redundant, leaving no sustained, separate damages recovery on that theory. The opinion therefore does not stand as authority that a landlord’s failure to timely repair a specific defect (such as electrical wiring) violated quiet enjoyment and deprived the tenant of full use of the premises.
See *Simon v. Solomon*, 385 Mass. 91, 95.relevant_excerpt: “The jury found in answer to a special question… that the water interfered with Solomon’s quiet enjoyment of her apartment. Therefore, Gem is liable under G. L. c. 186, § 14. … In sum, we hold that… Gem is liable to Solomon under § 14 because it violated its underlying duty to maintain sanitary conditions in her apartment, and thereby permitted repeated flooding to occur that interfered with her quiet enjoyment of her apartment. … Accordingly, we vacate [the $10,000 quiet enjoyment award].”

*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.proposition: A landlord’s failure to address unsafe or defective conditions that substantially interfere with a tenant’s use of the property constitutes a breach of the covenant of quiet enjoyment. *Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850-51 (1997).
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.support_reasoning: The opinion holds that liability under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment requires at least negligent conduct by the landlord, and it expressly cites as examples cases where a landlord’s failure to repair known defects violated § 14. The court notes that a landlord’s failure to repair defects of which he has notice, where the natural and probable consequence is interference with the tenant’s use and enjoyment, constitutes a breach. Thus, a failure to address unsafe or defective conditions that substantially interfere with use fits within the rule the case articulates.
*Al-Ziab v. Mourgis*, 424 Mass. 847, 850.relevant_excerpt: We noted that a landlord’s failure “to repair defects of which he has notice in leased premises is an omission which frequently has been deemed to violate § 14.” See Cruz, supra at 789, citing Simon v. Solomon, supra at 103 (failure to control floods in tenant’s apartment); Darmetko v. Boston Hous. Auth., 378 Mass. 758, 761 (1979) (failure to repair leaky roof); Dorgan v. Loukas, 19 Mass. App. Ct. 959, 960 (1985) (failure to bring apartment into habitable condition and keep it so). Today we make clear what was implicit in those rulings: to support the imposition of liability under the quiet enjoyment statute, there must be a showing of at least negligent conduct by a landlord…

See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authorit.raw_text: See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authorit.proposition: The inability to access and use one bedroom for more than six weeks has substantially and unreasonably interfered with Plaintiff’s use of the property, rendering Defendant liable for damages. See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority*, 417 Mass. 273, 284 (1994).
See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authorit.case_name: Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority
See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authorit.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns inability to use **one bedroom for more than six weeks** as a substantial and unreasonable interference with use of property. Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authority deals with tenants’ inability to use *common areas* (sidewalks, streets, parking lots, recreation areas) due to drug activity and analyzes this under the statutory covenant of quiet enjoyment. The court does not discuss loss of use of a single bedroom, any specific time period such as six weeks, or hold that such a condition by itself renders a landlord liable for damages. The case generally recognizes that serious interference with use of premises can breach quiet enjoyment, but it does not establish the specific rule asserted in the proposition.
See *Doe v. New Bedford Housing Authorit.relevant_excerpt: “In this case, we have no doubt that, if the plaintiffs truly are unable to use the common areas of the development, including sidewalks, streets, parking lots, and recreation areas within it, then the situation constitutes a serious interference with their quiet enjoyment and substantially impairs the character of the leased premises. … If the defendant failed to take any action to remove from the area of its control persons engaged in unlawful activity, then the defendant permitted a condition to exist that substantially interfered with the tenancies of the plaintiffs and thus breached the covenant of quiet enjoyment.”

See *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734,.proposition: Defendant's failure to repair the electrical wiring is a willful and unreasonable failure to act, entitling Plaintiff to damages under Massachusetts General Laws ch. 186, § 14. See *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734, 740-41 (2014).
See *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734,.support_reasoning: The opinion in Sheehan v. Weaver concerns strict liability under G.L. c. 143, § 51 for State building code violations and the definition of “building.” It does not analyze or apply G.L. c. 186, § 14, nor does it address whether a landlord’s failure to repair (electrical wiring or otherwise) constitutes a willful and unreasonable failure to act under that statute. The proposition about willful failure to repair entitling a tenant to c. 186, § 14 damages is therefore not supported by this case.
See *Sheehan v. Weaver*, 467 Mass. 734,.relevant_excerpt: “The issues we address in this appeal are, first, whether § 51 applies to all State building code violations… and second, whether the property involved in this case qualifies as a ‘building’ within the meaning of the statute… For the foregoing reasons, we now overrule the holding in McAllister and determine that… § 51 applies to any violations of G. L. c. 143 and the State building code… Because the building code violations and Sheehan’s injury both occurred in the residential portion of the Rantoul structure, we consider whether that portion is a ‘building’ within the meaning of § 51.”

See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714.proposition: Defendant’s conduct has proximately caused Plaintiff financial harm and significant emotional distress. See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714, 716-17 (1977).
See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns constructive eviction and breach of the implied covenant of quiet enjoyment due to noise from a lounge and the landlord’s control over that condition. It does not discuss proximate causation of financial harm or emotional distress, nor does it address damages for emotional distress at all. The case is authority for when a landlord’s conduct/omissions constitute constructive eviction, not for a general tort-style proposition about proximate cause of financial and emotional harm.
See *Blackett v. Olanoff*, 371 Mass. 714.relevant_excerpt: “There are occasions, however, where a landlord has not intended to violate a tenant’s rights, but there was nevertheless a breach of the landlord’s covenant of quiet enjoyment which flowed as the natural and probable consequence of what the landlord did, what he failed to do, or what he permitted to be done.”
